qas.question: What made Pacinotti's motor an important advancement?
Who created a motor similar to Pacinotti?
How far from each other were the motors in Gramme's demonstrations?
Besides a motor, what did Gramme use the other device for?
In what two cities did Gramme conduct his demonstrations?
What made Pacinotti's motor an unimportant advancement?
Who created a motor very different from Pacinotti?
How similar were the motors in Gramme's demonstrations?
Besides a motor, what didn't Gramme use the other device for?
In what two cities did Gramme never conduct his demonstrations?

context: A major turning point in the development of DC machines took place in 1864, when Antonio Pacinotti described for the first time the ring armature with its symmetrically grouped coils closed upon themselves and connected to the bars of a commutator, the brushes of which delivered practically <a0_0><b5_0>non-fluctuating current<b5_0/><a0_0/>. The first commercially successful DC motors followed the invention by <a1_0><b6_0>Zénobe Gramme<b6_0/><a1_0/> who, in 1871, reinvented Pacinotti's design. In 1873, Gramme showed that his dynamo could be used as a motor, which he demonstrated to great effect at exhibitions in <a4_0><b9_0>Vienna and Philadelphia<b9_0/><a4_0/> by connecting two such DC motors at a distance of up to <a2_0><b7_0>2 km<b7_0/><a2_0/> away from each other, one as a <a3_0><b8_0>generator<b8_0/><a3_0/>. (See also 1873 : l'expérience décisive [Decisive Workaround] .)
